abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the enterprise development
            project for Mozambique were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: Putting in place adequate
            monitoring and evaluation system should be an integral part
            of the project's design. In projects with a diverse set
            of local partners and donors, the project team should ensure
            that the selected implementing agency has adequate
            competency and commitment to handle all administrative,
            financial, and reporting functions. The Bank's
            financial supervision of projects can be strengthened by
            escalating early on accounting or financial errors that
            appear to be of a systemic nature and ensuring that
            financial management addresses any identified weaknesses.
            Transition and post-completion arrangements should be
            planned well in advance of project closing. A successful
            matching grant program for business services requires a
            combination of international expertise, local knowledge,
            autonomy in administration, and adaptability to respond to
            market demand. Government agencies' role in overseeing
            credit lines for small and medium enterprises should be
            limited to ensuring adherence to development mandate and
            overall portfolio quality.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Development Project aims
            to broaden the base of private participation in
            Mozambique's economic growth. The project consists of
            three components: 1) The technical learning in firms
            component will focus on building the technical capabilities
            of majority Mozambican-owned firms in manufacturing and
            exports. The component will support the establishments of
            the Firm Competitiveness Office, Training and Advisory
            Office, and Linkage Program Office. All three foster
            technical learning through the private marketplace. 2) Under
            the finance component, two financial products will be
            available for firms in all sectors -- a special facility
            designed to provide small, first-time bank borrowers with
            loans amounting to a maximum of $15,000; and a traditional
            facility to finance loans up to $300,000 for small and
            medium-scale borrowers. 3) The institutional capacity
            building component will enhance the capabilities of private
            and public institutions to deliver business support
            services; and support Government agencies in their
            transformation process from maintaining control functions to
            providing business facilitation and promotion services,
            including improving their capability to identify and ease
            bureaucratic rigidities.
